newsitem.title: GERMANY: EU's Santer sees EMU convergence efforts on track.
newsitem.headline: EU's Santer sees EMU convergence efforts on track.

text.p: European Commission President Jacques Santer said on Tuesday he was confident European Union states would continue to strive to meet the convergence criteria required for a successful common European currency.
Santer told the Global 24 European Monetary Conference that the bulk of legal steps needed to launch the euro on January 1 1999 had been taken, but more efforts were needed.
"Firstly member states need to persevere in their convergence efforts so that the currency union can begin with a sufficient number of countries," Santer said.
"And this will be the case. Too much is at stake for any states to ease up their efforts," he said.
Santer said more efforts were required to inform the public about the changes the euro would bring.
In addition, more attention must be paid to the external aspects of the move to a single currency, as some portfolio shifts would probably occur as a result of the euro launch.
Overall, Santer said, the euro would be beneficial for international trade, bringing new opportunities for exporters in the region.
He said he was confident monetary policy in the euro zone would be stable and fiscal policies would also be held steady.
The Global 24 European Monetary Union conference involves video-link ups with participants in Milan, New York, Paris and Tokyo.
